q: What are the symptoms of a stroke?
a: The main symptoms of a stroke can be remembered with the word FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, and Time to call emergency services.

q: How are strokes caused?
a: Strokes can be caused by either a blood clot blocking the blood supply to the brain (ischemic stroke) or a weakened blood vessel bursting and causing bleeding in the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).

q: How are strokes treated?
a: Strokes are usually treated with medications to prevent and dissolve blood clots, reduce blood pressure, and lower cholesterol levels. In some cases, procedures and surgery may also be required.

q: What are the long-term effects of a stroke?
a: Survivors of a stroke may experience long-term problems due to brain injury. Some people require rehabilitation to regain independence, while others may need ongoing support with daily activities.

q: How can strokes be prevented?
a: You can reduce your risk of stroke by maintaining a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, moderate alcohol consumption, and quitting smoking. Managing underlying conditions like high blood pressure or high cholesterol is also important.

q: Can children have strokes?
a: Yes, strokes can also occur in children. According to the Stroke Association, around 400 children in the UK experience a stroke each year.

q: What is a transient ischaemic attack (TIA)?
a: A transient ischaemic attack (TIA), also known as a mini-stroke, occurs when the blood supply to the brain is temporarily interrupted. It is considered a warning sign of an increased risk of a full stroke.
